comment: Hi, I dont understand one thing. For Derivative of L wrt w3, he didn't use the chain rule that we derived in the previous lecture. He just kept on derivating everything wrt w3. Did I miss anything?
love it

at 20:30 it has nothing to do with getting stuck when he explains which wrt what part we take derivative. we need to take derivate wrt to a2 simply because there is a functional relationship between a2 and w2. On the other hand, and from the perspective of forward propagation, derivative of w2 wrt w3 and&or b3 seems to be zero, correct?
I think at 24:13 he is wrong. It should be only (a[3]-y), without a[2]T? It makes no sense that dL/dz[3] is equal what he has written?
I'm in love with this guy. he teaches so good!
Finally messi cut his hair .

Now I'm quite confused. When calculating the back propagation formula, we have to find the partial derivative of the sigmoid function but it's meant to be a vector. And the derivative will be a matrix. But when calculating it he treats it as a scalar. Some other videos also do it this way. Why?
I am confused on why we removed (a[2])T from the equation at @ 26:37

During the last lecture, I really wanted him to teach this lecture as well, if Dr. Ng was absent. So I checked the thumbnail of this lecture and became so frustrated when I saw a different guy teaching. But, with a hesitation, I decided to move on. Then I heard his accent. I got truly excited. Nice haircut! I guess I need to train my brain to identify people correctly.
53:00 this note for me
Improving NN at 34:04
Exceptional instructor.. such concepts have never been clearer. Le meilleur!
Kian is the cutest!
Miss his long hair, he looked like Leo Messi in Lecture 11

1:14:30 - Well, the analogy of the rocket was a good one, but the momentum method is not like friction in any way.  Friction never "keeps you going" - it only ever tries to slow you down (or keep you from starting to move).  It universally opposes whatever motion is going on or trying to go on.

26:00 - this "using the shape" makes me nervous.  Will it always be the case that that will give you the right answer?  Are their possible architectures in which some of these matrices might be square?  In that case the transpose has the same dimension as the original.  I'd like to just know what I'm doing well enough to know what to do without needing a "cue" of that sort.
Very good! I am having a bit of trouble understanding when he is speaking about the Capital W and when he is referring to a lower case w.
He is by far the best teacher I have ever seen, Wow!!
Kian Katanforoosh is a very good teacher. He explains these concepts in such a way so that they appear simple to the listener.
corrected his mistake at 26:37
Because a[2]T is the result of the term dz[3]/dw[3] (the term he wrote in red marker below). It is not part of the term (dL/da[3])(da[3]/dz[3]), which is just (a[3]-y).
Oh I c , I see someone getting too emotional and sentimental n less rational. Anyway all well that ends well 🎉
you have problems.
@ruchevsk3165  ofcourse i needed to hear it from you

If you have two layers both of size N that are fully connected then the weight matrix that connects those two layers will be a square NxN matrix.  In that case you are correct that simply "using the shape" doesn't tell you whether you want the variable or its transpose when you derive these equations.  This "using the shape" trick is a good sanity check that you haven't made a transpose or dimensionality mistake but it is really not necessary.  A very careful application of the gradient operator and linear algebra will give you the same answer he derived and those equations will work for all matrix sizes (square, wide and tall).

you also have to be aware that there are more than one convention. There is the numerator and denominator scheme (here denominator is used) and some mixed forms https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_calculus#Identities
I think so!
I think all Andrew Ng TA's teach well but this guy is def the best out of three and Anan guy was the hardest one to understand
It's so true!
